Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase II: Splintered Topologically Close-Packed (TCP) Offload Engine for Grid Computing and Bandwith-Delay Product (BWDP)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase II research project addresses the challenges of networks with extreme bandwidth delay products. Bulk data transfer over such networks used by national research laboratories and aerospace companies need to be provided with the endpoint resources required to ensure high performance in a cost effective manner. The outcomes of this project attempts to provide compatibility with present and future versions of GridFTP. The project addresses these challenges through the use of a novel offload engine. During the Phase I project, the feasibility of deriving and simulating the offload engine architecture, firmware, and creation of intellectual property (IP) for low-cost, high-performance field programmable gate array (FPGA) subsystems was completed.

Successful results from this research will significantly advance the state of the art for off-load engines used in grid computing. Immediate applications include accommodating the e-Science community's need for scalable 10-100 Gbps off-load engines, while supporting present and future versions of GridFTP. Other applications include the use of our ultra high-speed offload engines for grid and cluster computing, utilizing our open source firmware. The FPGA code resulting from this project has the potential to be used as intellectual property that could then be marketed to off-load engine manufacturers. These IP cores would accrue cost-effective savings for existing engine firms and would accelerate products to the market.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SeaFire’s new network acceleration protocol, Grid-X, Splintered TCP, offers a faster, less expensive mechanism for cloud, grid, and cluster supercomputing data transfer.

  The SeaFire Alpha-stage prototype was integrated, assembled, and programmed, and completed.     Our consultant from Argonne National Laboratory (ANL) reviewed and advised us on our draft specification for the next interface between their cutting edge Grid computing file transfer protocol and our new network acceleration protocol.  ANL worked with SeaFire on installation, setup, and running their file transfer mechanism with our new prototype system.  ANL then guided and advised SeaFire on all such experiments.  The architecture, user environment, data transfer rates, and software processes were demonstrated to our commercial partner NASA through internet-based video conferences, presentations,  and videos.  

     SeaFire Alpha-stage prototype performance improved to 20%-40% of network line speed per channel, which is a breakthrough for our new network acceleration protocol.  Single host system and system-on-chips passed data at 100% of the network line speed but only for tests internal to the computer with our chips.  Two hosts had initially passed data through standard Grid computing file transfer protocol through 50% and during our 6-month project extension we were able to improve this up to 80% channel bandwidth.  Bottlenecks were identified, a resolution plan was formulated, and a technical specification was created for the interface between our new protocol and the Grid computing file transfer protocol in order to approach network line rate.

       Products:  SeaFire Alpha-stage prototype for future use by commercial partner tests in environments with multiples of 10 Gigabit Ethernet through 100 Gigabit Ethernet.  Technical documentation for prospective customers were created in the form of White Papers, where we review the perspectives and limitations of present central processor based systems, improvements in computer performance when using our invention, and applications for the sectors of cloud computing, stock trading, video acceleration, and supercomputing.  The network acceleration technology will be licensed based on “Network Acceleration Techniques,” US Patent Application Publication, No. US 2009/0168799 A1, Jul 2, 2009, which was a commercial contribution by SeaFire.

 


Last Modified: 02/02/2011
Modified by: James M Awrach

The SeaFire Alpha-stage prototype was integrated, assembled, and programmed, and completed. Our consultant from Argonne National Laboratory (ANL) reviewed and advised us on our draft specification for the next interface between their cutting edge Grid computing file transfer protocol and our new network acceleration protocol. ANL worked with SeaFire on installation, setup, and running their file transfer mechanism with our new prototype system. ANL then guided and advised SeaFire on all such experiments. The architecture, user environment, data transfer rates, and software processes were demonstrated to our commercial partner NASA through internet-based video conferences, presentations, and videos. SeaFire Alpha-stage prototype performance improved to 20%-40% of network line speed per channel, which is a breakthrough for our new network acceleration protocol. Single host system and system-on-chips passed data at 100% of the network line speed but only for tests internal to the computer with our chips. Two hosts had initially passed data through standard Grid computing file transfer protocol through 50% and during our 6-month project extension we were able to improve this up to 80% channel bandwidth. Bottlenecks were identified, a resolution plan was formulated, and a technical specification was created for the interface between our new protocol and the Grid computing file transfer protocol in order to approach network line rate. Technical documentation for prospective customers were created in the form of White Papers, where we review the perspectives and limitations of present central processor based systems, improvements in computer performance when using our invention, and applications for the sectors of cloud computing, stock trading, video acceleration, and supercomputing. The network acceleration technology will be licensed based on "Network Acceleration Techniques," US Patent Application Publication, No. US 2009/0168799 A1, Jul 2, 2009, which was a commercial contribution by SeaFire.
